story.storybody:
"The business of the poet and the novelist is to show the sorriness underlying the grandest things and the grandeur underlying the sorriest things."

No, we did not say this! The famous quote is from the poet and novelist, Thomas Hardy. The Order of Merit gave us well-known novels like Tess of the d'Urbervilles, Jude the Obscure, Far from the Madding Crowd and fantasies like The Well-Beloved, Two on a Tower and A Pair of Blue Eyes.

Today is his 176th birth anniversary! Let's celebrate the eminent author's birth anniversary by knowing some facts about his life:

  • Thomas Hardy went to school at the age of eight. His mother, Jemima, was pretty well-read which is why she educated him until he took admission
  • The 'Hardys' were not financially strong so he had to end his formal education at the age of 16. He then started learning architecture before moving to London
  • Due to his poor financial conditions, Hardy was conscious of social inferiority and class divisions in London
  • Hardy destroyed his first manuscript "The Poor Man and the Lady". It was said that his friend George Meredith asked him not to publish it since it was politically controversial
  • It is believed that Hardy coined the term "cliffhanger" after one of his protagonists was left hanging from a cliff
  • 'Jude the Obscure' was published in 1895. It received a lot of negative criticism for its controversial treatment of sex, marriage and religion. It is believed that Hardy stopped writing novels after that
  • Jude the Obscure also strained Hardy's marriage with Emma Hardy because Emma was concerned that the novel would be read as an autobiography
  • He was influenced by William Wordsworth, Charles Dickens and George Eliot
  • In 1910, he was awarded the Order of Merit and was also nominated for Nobel Prize in Literature.

And, here is another inspirational quote by him: "Life is to be felt, not figured out!"
